page.title: 15LANGENHOE MARSH
page.content: Langenhoe marsh is a fresh-marsh protected by a sea-wall from the high spring-tides which once covered it.Rain and snow have gradually leached the salt out of the soil.It is important for hen-harriers,merlin and short-eared owls in winter as well as great numbers of seed-eating migrants. Adders and grass-snake colonies are found sunning themselves along the sea-walls in places.Numerous varieties of salt-marsh and grassland plants grow here,providing food for many threatened species of butterflies and moths,such as the Essex Emerald moth. Rare dragonflies and damsels abound near the brackish pools,as well as some uncommon bush-crickets.This area acts as a home for many small mammals, such as voles,shrews and harvest mice,as well as foxes.
